DeregistrationReasonOtherText: All chemicals returned to vender on 7-22-11

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Columbus Waste Water Treatment Plant was originally prepared and submitted in June 1999.  The RMP for this facility has been updated to meet the 5 year update requirement by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.  Updated changes to the 1999 RMP include: 1) the requirement that information on reportable chemical accidents be added to the RMP within 6 months of the accident date; 2) the requirement that changes to the emergency contact information be reported within 1 month; 3) the removal of the original requirement to include a brief description of the off-site consequence analysis (OCA) in the Executive Summary of the RMP; and 4) the addition of 3 data elements to the RMP consisting of: emergency contact e-mail addresses if the addresses exist; b) the purpose and type of any submission that revises or otherwise affects the previously filed RMP; and c) the name, address, and telephone number of the contractor/consultant whoprepared the updated RMP.


Columbus Waste Water Treatment Plant and Regulated Substances Handled

The Columbus Waste Water Treatment Plant (Columbus WWTP) treats most of the waste water for the City of Columbus, Indiana.  The processes at the plant include mixing, sedimentation control, flocculation, filtration, aeration, clarification, and chlorination of waste water from the City of Columbus with discharge to the East Fork of the White River.  The only regulated substances used at the plant are chlorine anhydrous sulfur dioxide.  The facility purchases pressurized cylinders that are filled with 2,000 pounds of liquified chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  A total of 10,000 pounds of each of these substances could be stored at the plant at any one time.


Accidental Release Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Columbus WWTP  is covered by the Emergency Planning and Right-to-Know (EPCRA) program and the OSHA Process Management Plan requirements.  The only substances representing a hazard to huma

ns and the environment is the potential toxic release of chlorine and sulfur dioxide gases.  Potential releases of chlorine gas could occur from pressurized cylinders damaged during unloading and potential release from material failure of the vacuum relief valve on each gas cylinder.  The facility has the following process controls in place to reduce the risk of chlorine and sulfur dioxide: vessel relief valves, manual shutoff controls, automatic shutoffs, gas detection alarms, and rupture disks.  When the outer access doors to the gas cylinder storage room are closed, the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage building provides significant passive control and mitigation of chlorine and sulfur dioxide gases escape from the facility.  Pursuant to U.S. EPA guidance, the storage building passive control could reduce the rate of chlorine and sulfur dioxide gases release to the environment by approximately 55%.  Chlorine gas leaks can be detected through the use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas sensors within the storage room area and in the process room.


Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Columbus has a strong commitment to the protection of the public and environment from releases of hazardous chemicals from any of its facilities.  The individual facility managers are responsible for safe operating and maintenance of all potentially hazardous treatment processes as well as the enforcement of emergency response policies.  Guidance and policies for the handling of accidental releases of hazardous substances at its facilities are provided by: 1) a Process Safety Management Plan (June 1999); and a 2) Comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (under the direction of the Office of Emergency Preparedness.  All personnel that work with facilities process equipment using hazardous substances, receive training in safety and emergency response procedures.  


Five-Year Accident History

The Plant Manager of the Columbus WWTP has stated that the facility

has not had any reportable releases of chlorine or anhydrous sulfur dioxide gas during the past 5 years.


Emergency Response Program

The Columbus WWTP facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to cover procedures in the event of a release of hazardous chemicals from its facility. The EAP is included in the Bartholemew County Local Emergency Planning Commission emergency response and contingency plan.  The Columbus WWTP employees of the City of Columbus Utilities Department are trained in emergency response procedures and practices on the job on a regular basis by qualified senior staff and management.  Employees receive training on responding to emergency releases of hazardous chemicals.
